intro: Paepalanthus diplobetor, commonly known as the two-seeded puya, is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a striking plant characterized by its tall, spiky inflorescence and vibrant, showy flowers that range in color from red to orange. The plant produces two small, fleshy seeds enclosed in a specialized structure called a "puya," which is unique to the genus Paepalanthus. It thrives in high-altitude environments with cool temperatures and requires well-drained soil. Due to its ecological importance and ornamental value, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
